newsitem.title: BELGIUM: QUICK THINKS CHICKEN AFTER BEEF SCARE.
newsitem.headline: QUICK THINKS CHICKEN AFTER BEEF SCARE.

text.p: Belgian hamburger restaurant chain operator Quick NV said on Friday it plans to offer more chicken-based products after net profit plunged 48 percent in 1996 because of the mad cow scare.
"Beef remains our core business, but we are planning to launch new products, notably based on chicken," Quick CEO Thomas Meisser told a news conference.
He said that for every 100 meals sold in the second half of 1996, 15 percent were chicken-based, compared to nine percent in the first half of 1995.
Quick reported 1996 earnings fell to 312 million Belgian francs from 598 million francs despite a 10 percent rise in sales to 21.5 billion francs.

Quick blamed the drop on the panic over beef that followed the exposure of a possible link between bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) and brain disease in humans and price competition with arch rivals McDonald's .
"The European crisis over mad cow disease has led to changes in the eating patterns of a number of consumers, who until now have not regained full confidence in beef," Meisser said.
Meisser said Quick expected sales to grow another 10 percent in 1997, but would not venture a profit forecast.
As well as launching new products, the group would also seek to expand faster in the Netherlands, opening 50 to 70 new stores there before the year 2000.
At the end of 1996 Quick had 105 restaurants in Belgium, 258 in France (which account for the bulk of its sales), five in the Netherlands and three in Luxembourg.
